newsitem.title: RUSSIA: ENVIRONMENTALISTS OPPOSE MOSCOW-ST PETERSBURG HIGH-SPEED RAILWAY.
newsitem.headline: ENVIRONMENTALISTS OPPOSE MOSCOW-ST PETERSBURG HIGH-SPEED RAILWAY.

text.p: A multi-billion dollar project to build a high-speed rail link between Moscow and St Petersburg is awaiting the green light from Russia's environmental authorities, but has run up against opposition by ecology groups.

"There is no concrete work under way yet as the project has not been approved," said Andrei Filippov, an official at the foreign relations and ecology department of state-owned RAO Vysokoskorostnye Magistrali (VSM, or High-Speed Railways).

But environmentalists complain that VSM has already started research work and de-mining along a new route. Army units have dug out hundreds of land mines and shells left from the World War Two in an expensive operation.
The $5-5.50 billion project will cut the journey time between Russia's two biggest cities to about two hours from an overnight trip of eight, enabling rail to compete with domestic airlines.

Initially the company considered two plans -- reconstructing the line built in the middle of the last century or building a totally new 654 km (400 mile) track for trains to carry passengers at more than 200 km (125 miles) an hour.
VSM now says the existing line is heavily congested.
"Now the company is pressing ahead with only one option -- a new line which will cross several national parks," said Greenpeace coordinator Ivan Blokov.
"It is an awful idea. They already have an old line, with pollution all around it, so they should build it there."
COMPANY HAS ALREADY RAISED MILLIONS FOR PROJECT
VSM has already raised hundreds of millions of dollars in shares, government-guaranteed bonds and loans for the project.

First Deputy Prime Minister Alexei Bolshakov, whose responsibilities include transport, was head of St Petersburg- based VSM before joining the cabinet. Bolshakov said in mid-1994 that the first section of the line could be finished this year, but the project is still on the drawing board.

Gennady Chegasov, head of the state ecology inspection department at the Ecology Ministry said VSM had not presented a concrete project and feasibility study to the ministry for approval and that no work was legally allowed.

"VSM may not start any work before an expert commission has worked out its recommendations on a feasibility study," Chegasov said, noting that an earlier examination of a preliminary VSM plan had thrown up many irregularities which had to be taken into account in a new project.
The commission, to be appointed by the ministry, will recommend to the government and regional authorities whether the plan should go ahead or not.

The Nezavisimaya Gazeta daily this month quoted professor Alexei Yablokov, head of the Russian Ecology Policy Centre, as saying the Russian government had allocated 9.5 trillion roubles ($1.5 billion) in state guarantees under the project for 1997.
"I am ashamed of the government, for helping such adventurers...participating in this cash-spending orgy," he said.

Blokov quoted activists in Tver region as saying the local administration was considering a referendum on the rail link. But Tvery deputy governor Mikhail Zorin told Reuters there was no talk of a referendum yet.

"Our legislators will discuss the issue later this month. We want to settle some problems, including ecological ones, with the company, but I would not say that we have any hardline opposition to the project."
PROTESTS OVER NEW ST PETERSBURG STATION
Ecologists in St Petersburg have protested against the demolition of old buildings to make space for a new railway station.

The government has approved the construction of a railway terminus, with a station, hotel, shopping centre, offices and car park in St Petersburg with a $200 million British loan. The terminus is being built by the British construction company Taylor Woodrow.
But one government official, who asked not to be named, said the conflicting interests of foreign companies competing for the project, as well as ecological issues, was fomenting opposition.
"We have British capital here on the one hand and Franco-German high-speed railway technology on the other. Ecology is just one excuse in their war of interests."
